snp1.10:181: “What here is a person’s best treasure?What well practiced brings happiness?What is really the sweetest of tastes?How lives the one whose life they say is best?” (1)
snp1.10:182: “Faith is here a person’s best treasure;the Dhamma well practiced brings happiness;truth is really the sweetest of tastes;living by wisdom, they say, one’s life is best.” (2)
snp1.10:183: “How does one cross the flood?How does one cross the sea?How does one overcome suffering?How is one fully purified?” (3) [33]
snp1.10:184: “By faith one crosses the flood,by heedfulness one crosses the sea.By energy one overcomes suffering;by wisdom one is fully purified.” (4)
snp1.10:185: “How does one gain wisdom?How does one find wealth?How does one achieve acclaim?How does one bind friends?When passing from this world to the next,how does one not sorrow?” (5)
snp1.10:186: “Placing faith in the Dhamma of the arahantsfor the attainment of nibbāna,one gains wisdom from a desire to learnif one is heedful and astute. (6)
snp1.10:187: “Doing what is proper, dutiful,one with initiative finds wealth.By truthfulness one wins acclaim;by giving, one binds friends.The parallel at SN I 215,2has a couplet here not in the Sn version:asmā lokā paraṃ lokaṃ, evaṃ pecca na socati, “That is how one does not sorrow when passing from this world to the next.”(7)
snp1.10:188: “The faithful seeker of the household lifewho possesses these four qualities —truth,dhamma, steadfastness, generosity —does not sorrow when he passes on. (8)
snp1.10:189: “Come now, ask the others as well,the many ascetics and brahmins,whether there exists here anything betterthan truth, self-control, generosity, and patience.” (9)
